Does not work with Quest controllers, you must use a gamepad!!

This game is basically Dark Souls for VR. Camera is fixed, but it's totally ok. Graphics are absolute top. Very good game of shadows, lightenings and very nice textures. Sound patterns, and everything around sound is great. Game is not just some stupid hack'n'slash adventure. It's coming with LOTS of original and very surprising mechanics, for example aging 1 year on death is very good idea. Combats are fun. I'm playing it on hardest difficulty (one of three) and it's very challanging (and I'm pretty sure I will not finish it on my first time). Story is good, and simple to understand (not like Dark Souls). This is totally must have for anyone who have PCVR and Oculus headset.

review_title: I own 20 VR titles, and this is my Fav!
one_reviews_text: This game is amazing! Not only do I love the 3rd person perspective, the graphics are sooo good, and the controls are perfect *(just be careful of accidentally pressing Y button, as it will irritate you to no end lol) I managed to beat the game at age 60, but I was very meticulous, paying close attention to selecting particular skills, in order to achieve the most success. This game has great replay value, as I have all 3 save slots in various stages of life: young, middle aged, and elderly. Progression system is really cool as you have many different options and ways in which you can master your skills and level your character and weapons up. Like I said above, this is my favorite title! A must own, in my honest opinion. Happy gaming, and Goodluck with the final end boss: Dragon! He is psycho!

review_title: This shows the potential of VR
one_reviews_text:
I get motion sickness, so first person games in VR are hit or miss. If I can teleport I'm fine, if it's a walking type motion, I'm cooked. I was hesitant to buy this game, but boy was I wrong! The graphics are awersome, the story is awesome, and the expereince is immersive. This is just a fantastic game, even if you like first person. It's games like this that really highlight the power of VR. I wish that some of the bigger developers would get in the game. Imagine Abe's World, Dante's Inferno, God of War, Xcom, ect., all brought to life in VR. There is so much power here, so much promise. I hope the developers of this game keep going and produce more content. Fantastic job, fantastic game!

I see some people talking about the controls. All I can say is that my Oculus Rift S controllers did not work. The game didn't even start. So, I went and bought a Steelseries Stratus Duo, at Wallyworld. Right out the box it worked perfectly, and the game started up and worked fine. This controller mirrors an XBox, so if you know your way areound that, this controller should be no problem.
I have a problem with some games that my computer is too powerful to run them (RTX 3080 build). I've asked for a refund and it got cancelled due to a bug.

I have been using a VR headset for about 3 years now and this is still one of my top 5 favourite games/experiences to date. From the very beginning of this title I found it difficult to end it and take a break because I so wrapped up on the visuals, the story, the adventure. I just don’t understand why there’s no more games like this and because I would have them in my library in a heartbeat. So if you are looking for something new to try don’t miss this title it was amazing! ( Where are you Gunfire Games?)

A LOT of people say they don't understand what VR can do for the 3rd person gaming experience, and before Chronos, I was among them.  However, this is such a beautiful game.  Story, gameplay, music still compel me to write this review, even though I first played this when it released.  I figured every decent developer would quickly follow, but alas, my heart still yearns for this one.
I really wish I could erase that part of my mind and play this again for the first time...or they would at least make a sequel!?!

Cheers!

Not sure why they didn't go that route. review_title: Zelda and Dark Souls had a baby in VR
one_reviews_text: Title says it all. Gameplay is amazing. Graphics are amazing. Controls are your normal gamepad setup so they are fairly intuitive. The 3rd person view is a little unexpected in a VR title, but it works extremely well in this game. The game is challenging similar to Dark Souls, but it is forgiving enough that more casual players can get into it as well (especially if they play on easy, like my wife did) on the flip side dying is very much a part of the game, and while slightly annoying, can be used strategically to advance through the game.

review_title: Stuck, and I think it is a glitch.
one_reviews_text: I beat the second boss twice in given run throughs.  I am stuck, and I don't think the game actually progresses, there must be a glitch. I invested probably 25-30 hours into this title, and the walkthrough online is showing that you can progress, but I can not.  What is going on here?  Twice, two separate attempts, two separate computers.  I have been everywhere, there is a door that does not open, a path that can't be followed after beating a major boss, so I think the title is broken.

I played Remnant:From the Ashes before I even knew about this game and now I feel like I have played them out of order, as this was like a prequel. There is no doubt that Chronos ties into Remnant directly with the same environment, playstyle and many of the same enemies. Now I wish Remnant had a VR mode to it so I could play in the same manner. I managed to beat it in a bit over 11 hours playing on Adventure and even had a few moments of frustration. I think the one thing that kind of disappointed me is the constant changing of camera angle. One moment you are pushing right to go across the screen, go through a doorway to now need to press left to keep going in the same game direction. This became a bit frustrating when the changed direction could lead you off an edge. There were moments the mechanics of waiting for a hit to finish before you can dodge upset me, but it is kind of the same in Remnant and becomes all about timing and knowing your enemy.

I absolutely love the third person aspect in VR because it puts me in the environment with the character. I felt more emotionally attached to the character instead of it being me. In one area scale is used to make you smaller and then larger and it is perfect for VR. The game is mostly fighting enemies and collecting items to solve puzzles to gain access to the next area. The leveling and age mechanic with death is interesting and along with leveling up your weapon of choice, the only way to successfully get through the game. I want more games like this.

This game is awesome, graphics are beautiful, sound/music works very well with the environment. Character leveling works OK, I wish the magic use had more value, but fighting is really good, basically 2 options: Sword-n-Board or Dodge and strike. Replay could be better if the magic use had more options. Leveling weapons is slow at the start, and my first play-through I was quite discouraged, until later in the game when upgrades were readily available, and I had too many items to bother upgrading any weapon, the ones I could use for my fighting style were already maxed.
The environments are well done, and I found myself looking around a lot, capturing all the elements around me.
The puzzles are not too difficult, younger players can solve everything without much trouble.
3 difficulty settings also allow another play-through. Doing the middle-tier (Adventurer) worked very well for my first play though. I am starting my second play with the opposite fighting style, and doing the most difficult option. I expect, and want, to die often to age in this game. You get age-based abilities, and I didnt get past the first 2 my first time through.
This is why I gave this 4 stars. There's just a slight disconnect in leveling and aging and game progression. I really wanted to give this 5 stars!!! It is a very well done game!
This game is amazing.  It's like a cross between fallout and the legend of zelda.  Very cool concept.  Great graphics and gameplay.

The premise alone is worth looking into it; the aging of your character tweaking how your stat upgrades cost as your youth wanes and your mind expands, along with unique traits every 10 years to show your training in between. 
The visuals are stellar, no two ways about it. It's gorgeous and really shows off the VR Tech's graphics and detail capabilities, along with the sound design.
Gameplay wise, it's kind of like Dark Souls and Resident Evil. From RE it takes the fixed camera among the scenery:  and from Dark Souls it takes most of the combat's feel. Pick a Strong or Agility weapon type and then either block or dodgeroll your way to victory for most of the enemies. The parrying mechanic, however, kind of sucks since it's a risky proposition and if you scuff it, you're getting hit. To heal, you have Dragon Hearts which are basically estus flasks that only refill when you die and advance another year, making it very tense when you're low on health trying to push through a maze-like environment. Lots of looping around and doors opening from only one side with inventory puzzles dotted across them, though some of those puzzles are really cool, specifically in the early first area. Later on, they get less creative and more obvious once you have the pieces. The most blatantly boring one is a sliding tile puzzle near the end.
One of the troubles with the gameplay is that there are four stats you invest points into and one is pointless. Arcane only effects elemental damage to your chosen enchantment, no spells or anything cool, so just dump all your points in vitality and whichever melee type you want.
And the twists. I won't spoil. But the main twist is pretty obvious to savvy roleplayers. There's other stuff which is very cool and clever, but good luck seeing it on the first run. 
The ending? Disappointing. It feels like there should've been multiple endings and you got a bad one, but there's only one. Heard maybe sequel, but no guarantee.
Buy cheap.

It's a brilliant game in many aspects. The leveling and aging system is unique and interesting. The graphics are beautiful with many stunning places to explore. Gameplay is fun, challenging and engaging. If you like a challenge in your games with a slower progress as well as some exploration and puzzle solving then this is the game for you. I would have liked to see a few more options for ways to engage in combat and different kinds of weapons. The arcane stat is a bit lackluster in my opinion. I would have liked to see some more things done with magic in combat like some cool spells to throw out and not just making your weapon swings hit harder. These are minor details though, overall I had a ton of fun playing Chronos and will probably go back and play it again. The story ended on a cliffhanger which was a shame but hopefully that means we're getting a part two.

I would give the game 1 more star if the gameplay were better and 1 more if the ending were better. As it is, the gameplay suffers. There are essentially 3 major moves in combat: Hit, Block and Parry. Unfortunately, the timing for Parry is really hit-and-miss. It seems tied to the animation of the enemy you are fighting and if you do not hit the parry button at precisely the right point in the animation, you receive major damage. The other issue is the camera positions when going from one room to another. When transitioning from one room to another, the angle of the camera in relation to your character may be very different. Unfortunately, this means that if the character was going right along a ledge one room, in the next he will immediately be going left and over the cliff. 

Hearing Kate Mulgrew (Captain Janeway from Star Trek Voyager) tell the opening story was great. With as much effort as was put into the beginning story, and with all the effort put into the little scrolls and books throughout the game - how could the ending be so disappointing?

Overall, I would not recommend this game. If you put several hours into beating a game, it should feel rewarding.

review_title: Is this VR Darksouls? Pretty much!
one_reviews_text: Other than the stationary camera that changes depending on your location, Dark Souls fans are going to get the dose of Dark Souls victory and frustration (but if only if you play on hard.) The atmosphere is breathtaking, so stop and look around everyone once and a while. This game is unsettling, and carries with it a dark sci-fi fantasy overtone with moments that will make you turn tail and run to safety. Skill customization is low, and the game is personal-skill dependent: you're going to have to practice timing or 'get gud.' Not a game I'll showcase at a friend/family gathering, but one I love to play when I'm alone and can focus.  I have never experienced any glitches or interruptions playing on a 1060, and the load times are fairly quick. The levels seem to wrap in upon themselves much like Dark Souls 1, leading to some "Ah-Ha!" moments when you discover a great short cut. Great polish, and gorgeous design. Worth the money.

I saw lots of positive reviews, and it was on  sale, but now I wish I hadn't purchased it. The controls are frustrating. Good luck trying to just hit an enemy repeatedly, because your character just decides to spin to the side and expose himself to their blows.

Once you get used to the game it has some good points but mechanics are a bit stale and story is predictable (except the ending is even worse than expected - minus two stars)  Overall not worth the high price paid - wait for a good sale.

From very early on in the adventure, I could tell that Chronos was going to be a good example of what one could do with VR, it also holds up as a game on its own merits.

You play this game in third-person, your camera practically being a fly on the wall. I see a lot of people dreaming about what VR could be in first person, but this game might prove that a good old classical  third-person perspective has more potential. It smartly switches to first-person when one is examining an item in the environment, either to let you read a text or as an opportunity to use a key. 

The way it handles your perspective is smart, as it allows for a comfortable yet immersive experience that doesn't distract too much by disorienting you as less elegant VR games tends to do. It was impossible not to notice that when you switch camera position, the new angle is most likely going to be pointed to where your eyes are already focused, making transitions jump comfortably. 

Gameplay is competent. It focuses on a simple system, very much inspired by games such as Dark Souls. Most encounters with opponents take the form of a mostly satisfying duel with a single opponent, and most of them demand you learn their behaviour and rhythm. Any encounter with more than one enemy at a time becomes a challenge, and dealing with it carefully and strategically becomes vital.

So, overall I give this game praise. However...

One flaw that is worth pointing out is that this game feels a bit derivative at times. While many of the ideas it presents are nice, good for VR and certainly fit the tone and world they've created, I get the impression that a some of these ideas were taken from somewhere else, at times haphazardly. It's baby's first Dark Souls, and it doesn't feel like they thought all of it through. One example is an entire 'level' that reminds me too much of the Twilight Realm from Legend of Zelda: Twilight Princess. Maybe it's a tribute? 

Still, good game, and a great example of what VR can be.

review_title: Die, die, and die again tedium
one_reviews_text: Let me start with an admission. I am a casual gamer not exactly skilful. I played this game on the default adventure mode and died over and over and over again. Each time you die, any doors you have opened remain opened and any items collected stay in your inventory, but all the enemies respawn. So a typical scenario is fighting your way to a location, being killed, then respawning at the last portal and fighting your way all the way back to that location, only to die again and then have to restart. You acrue experience as you win battles which you use to level up so the battles ultimately become easier, not because you have mastered the combat, but because your blows now do more damage and you have a larger health bar. It's tedious in the extreme. Every 10 years you get a stat boost so eventually after reaching 60 years old I just decided to see what happened if I kept dying and how old I could become. I purposefully threw myself of a ledge 20 times and was finally told I had reached immortality. This had the benefit of giving me some stat boosts making the game easier, my weapons did more damage and I had an even bigger health bar, but I still kept dying though, immortality didn't stop that. The best thing about the game was that the wizened, gnarled appearance of my near dead character avatar at 80 years pretty much represented how ravaged I felt having endured 10 or so hours of this tedium. There are puzzles, but not really. Anything in the game that you can pick up glows. You pick them up. Then you come to a door or mechanism that requires an object to work. You go to your inventory, you try each object in turn and one of them will open the door. No thought required. At all. To cap it off the ending was terrible rendering the whole thing meaningless. I've had the game a few weeks and played it to completion so I can't claim a refund. I might contact Oculus though and ask if they can delete it from my system so I no longer have to see it on my home screen!

review_title: Spectacular art, comfy, but some issues
one_reviews_text: This game is the first of its kind in VR, a beautiful, third-person action/adventure RPG. Its unique choice to eschew locomotion and use a static camera not only makes it extremely comfortable but also enables its beautiful art by allowing each scene to have a range of elements at different depths and all of them at an appropriate level of detail. Its use of match cuts as you move from scene to scene prevents ever losing your character, and the worlds are carefully designed to embrace this constraint. My personal favorite art is the treehouses of the Pan, with delicate wooden bridges set amidst 500-foot trees with sunshine filtering through the canopy. The animation is no less perfect, with every walk, run, and climb revealing not the slightest flaw, even on staircases, which really helps keep you in the experience. And the use of scale, audio, and level design to create terrifying experiences like your first encounter with the Cyclops is unforgettable. █ The story and mechanics didn't click as well with me. No HUD is great for immersion, but without life meters, I fought the same battles over and over, never knowing if I had even come close to winning. And although you are given choices in designing and levelling up your character, they aren't meaningful. The strategy of levelling up strength/agility while you're young and arcane when you're older is obvious. Selecting strength vs. agility based on your preferred fighting style is a legitimate choice, but arcane feels useless, especially for boss battles, since it only provides a short, temporary buff and has a long cooldown. Many players also didn't realise the queen's scepter can be separated in the menu. █ Some parts of the story were fantastic - the magic mirror, the Dreamers, the princess, the Pan with riddles. But it left me with more questions than answers about the world. And like others, I feel like the ending was rushed and dissatisfactory. Overall: play it for the art, but I recommend casual mode!

review_title: Hate Dark Souls? Play Difficulty CASUAL
one_reviews_text:
I was really iffy about this game because I hate Dark Souls combat and find the difficulty of those games mind-numbingly stupid. However, this game on CASUAL is very much like Dark Souls light. As you progress through the game there are many times you do a part maybe 15-30 minutes that will link back to your original checkpoint so you can get through it piece by piece without having to rekill enemies many times if you do actually die.

If you pick up Chronos and just want to enjoy a Zelda-Esque title this is your game. I like games more like God of War, but the combat still is rewarding once you find the weapon you prefer. I personally hate games that force you to dodge all of the time like Dark Souls, and this game doesn't require it in every battle. You will do it in some fights, but if you make a Strength build you can just block and nullify the damage when you get a little further in the game. I personally like this playstyle since I can just chill out and when their attack animation is done I can just wail on them.

This is drastically different from someone with an Agility build that gets faster dodging and builds up defense as well, who depends more on quickness/parrying. So if you prefer or like timing things perfectly then you will probably like that build.

In casual, you really don't die very much and when you do it isn't really a big deal. It can be annoying that you have to kill the enemies again, but I didn't really find myself dying all that much unless I got completely careless so that is very reminicent of Dark Souls, but realistically I've only truly died like 3-4 times on my casual playthrough and like 5 of them are just me half-paying attention and falling in a hole.

TLDR: If you don't like the difficulty of Dark Souls then play CASUAL instead of normal/heroic and you should like it. It's a great action adventure RPG in VR with great music/sounds to immerse you in.

Chronos should be everyone's first full game in VR. After doing the demos and free stuff available on Oculus Home i would recommend any gamer to play this first. It's fixed camera makes it a smooth experience to ease  into VR and the gameplay is fantastic. If you like RPG games and solid gameplay with many hours of entertaining puzzels and combat.... then look no further!

The fighting mechanics in this game seem to be a bit inspired by Dark Souls, yet still feels like it's own. Actually I prefer the dodging in Chronos over Dark Souls. It feels more fluid and realistic as opposed to the rolling you do in Dark Souls. Great story and fun puzzles. Game was a blast and an adventure for sure. I wish it was longer. My favorite official VR game, even over Touch titles. Unofficial favorite still goes to Alien Isolation. One review says 'just buy Dark Souls'. Sure if it was VR. The VR aspect changes everything. It's amazing.
